newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Siege after gunman wounds two in Geneva church.
newsitem.headline: Siege after gunman wounds two in Geneva church.

text.p: Armed police on Sunday morning surrounded a church in the heart of Geneva where a former Swiss army major feared by police to be deranged was holed up after shooting and wounding a priest and an altarboy.
The 52-year-old Swiss German from the town of Basel was still inside Notre Dame Roman Catholic Church nearly five hours after the attack at 7.30 p.m. (1830 GMT), police said.
Police said the priest and an altarboy were wounded when the gunman opened fire with a pistol inside the church soon after evening mass ended.
"He's deranged, we think. We've sent in psychologists. They're trying to calm him down," he added. "If dialogue doesn't work, we'll have to use force," said police spokesman Alexander Baerisswyl.
The two wounded were removed from the church together with worshippers. They were taken to hospital where police said their wounds were not serious.
Police and a psychologist entered into negotiations with the gunman by mobile telephone to persuade him to surrender.
"He's asked for a mobile phone. He's been making phonecall after phonecall. He's demanded to see our city's police chiefs -- in uniform," said Baerissmyl.
Policemen with sniffer dogs moved around the edge of the church, which is near Geneva's main train station and the four-star Hotel Cornavin, apparently searching for explosives.
Outside the church, about a dozen police officers wearing flak jackets, black masks and helmets trained their guns on the building.
Geneva residents were shocked by the attack, the first they could remember in their tranquil city.
"There's a gunman down the road, haven't you heard?," an elderly Swiss lady in a black coat shouted at passers-by in a nearby backstreet.
A young police officer told a group of movie-goers asking what had happened: "There's been shooting. Someone has been shooting."
Switzerland has compulsory military service for men and every able-bodied Swiss male has an assault weapon at home. Switzerland has a 400,000-man militia army.
